Award.AwardTitle: BIGDATA: EAGER: Using Big Data to Investigate Longitudinal Education Outcomes through Visual Analytics

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
BIGDATA: Using Big Data to Investigate Longitudinal Education Outcomes through Visual Analytics

Data science techniques have revolutionized many academic fields and led to terrific gains in the commercial sector. They have to date been underutilized in solving critical problems in the US educational system, particularly in understanding Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics (STEM) learning and learning environments, broadening participation in STEM, and increasing retention for students traditionally underserved in STEM. The goals of the Directorate for Education and Human Resources (EHR), through the EHR Core Research program, for the Critical Techniques and Technologies for Advancing Foundations and Applications of Big Data Science & Engineering (BIGDATA) program are to advance fundamental research aimed at understanding and solving these critical problems, and to catalyze the use of data science in Education Research. This Early Concept Grant for Exploratory Research (EAGER) will employ data from national representative datasets including approximately 35,000 students to investigate course taking patterns in high school and how these relate to critical outcomes such as college attendance, high school and college success, and career choices. Few investigators have attempted to answer this question with this scale of data. Therefore, this proposal will contribute significantly to the field's understanding of factors that affect success in high school and college. Building on these new insights will enable the potential to create interventions at the high school and college level based on data about what works to improve graduation and workforce outcomes.

The Education Longitudinal Study of 2002-2012 (ELS:2002) and High School Longitudinal Study of 2009 (HSLS:2009) are representative samples of high school students who were tracked through college and into their early career. ELS has 15,000 students and HSLS has 21,000 students. For ELS, NCES surveyed students in 10th and 12th grade, then sophomore year of college, and then when they were approximately 26. NCES collected transcripts for high school and college, and high school and college achievement, attitudinal, participation and demographic variables. The Principal Investigator will first use visualizations to identify potential patterns of difference in outcomes and then use growth mixture modeling (GMM) and receiver operating characteristic analysis (ROC) to investigate the statistical significance of those patterns.

This award is supported by the EHR Core Research (ECR) program. The ECR program emphasizes fundamental STEM education research that generates foundational knowledge in the field. Investments are made in critical areas that are essential, broad and enduring: STEM learning and STEM learning environments, broadening participation in STEM, and STEM workforce development

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Goals and Objectives:

The goal of this project is to analyze large longitudinal big data US nationally generalizable education datasets to develop models of student progression in STEM fields (science, technology, engineering and mathematics) from high school, through college and into their careers at age 26. To identify successful student STEM course taking patterns through the high school and college curriculum, our research strategy involved applying big data visual analytic methods from other big data fields, such as bioinformatics, demography, and data mining, to education datasets. We applied the methods from these diverse fields to create novel visual data analytics that pattern and display the entire curriculum choice and performance patterns of students across a representative sample of high schools in the US using large datasets from the US Department of Education National Center for Education Statistics (NCES). Throughout this work, we identified novel student enrollment and achievement patterns that predict early career STEM outcomes.

In this project, we tested various approaches for visualizing and analyzing the data, adapting methods and models from other big data fields. Our intention is to help the education research field visualize the patterns in curriculum and achievement data in new ways that allow for researchers, practitioners and students to visualize and see patterns across the high school enrollment and student performance data that have not been evident through past research. In applying these new visual analytic approaches, the research and practice fields around understanding successful student progression in STEM fields from high school through college and into careers will be able to describe and understand the previously unknown patterns of successful students from these large complex education datasets. Given that the results from the large national-level datasets provide an overall view of the patterns of STEM student curriculum enrollment and performance, we have also worked to test and pilot open source code from the R software package. The R code allows researchers and the general public to analyze similar enrollment and curriculum data themselves within these new visualization methods to allow practitioners to visualize the entire enrolled curriculum differences between their own schools, districts, states, groups of students and different student outcomes. This work potentially pinpoints localized curricular offerings and issues that either promote or hinder student progression within the STEM schooling pipeline.

Our goals in this project were to:

1) Pilot and test visualization pattern analytics with the large NCES datasets and develop the code for the visualization and pattern analysis in R.

2) Create a tool online for educators and researchers to use that provides the analytics in R without them needing to know the code

3) Use pattern analysis to examine empirically defined subgroups of STEM students, schools, and families to examine long-term STEM student career outcomes

4) Test the accuracy of multiple predictors of STEM and school success indicators.
